section.title: Using Buffers with BlackTie
section.para: BlackTie supports all three of the buffer types defined in the XATMI specification.
BlackTie also supports the Nested Buffer Format described below.

section.title: X_OCTET
section.para: The X_OCTET buffer type operates exactly as per is defined within Chapter 9 of the specification with the following points of interest:

listitem.para: A non-zero size MUST be provided to tpalloc and tprealloc calls
The entire buffer is initialized to \0 (NULL) prior to returning to the client

section.title: X_COMMON/X_C_TYPE
section.para: For our implementation of these buffer types we have required the user to configure the structure of the buffer in the btconfig.xml

section.title: How to use Nested Buffers in BlackTie
Defining a schema
section.para: Nested Buffer Format is defined in a xsd schema file, such as employee.xsd:
All xsd schema files should been placed in buffers directory.
Get a nested buffer in blacktie, you should use

para.programlisting: char* buffer = tpalloc("BT_NBF", "<buffer_name>", 0); // in C++ BT_NBF buffer = (BT_NBF) connection.tpalloc("BT_NBF", "<buffer_name>", 0); // in Java

section.para: After that, the following options are available:

listitem.para: add a new attribute in buffer
int btaddattribute(char** buf, char* attributeId, char* attributeValue, int len); // in C++
int btgetattribute(char* buf, char* attributeId, int attributeIndex, char* attributeValue, int* len); // in C++
int btsetattribute(char** buf, char* attributeId, int attributeIndex, char* attributeValue, int len); // in C++
int btdelattribute(char* buf, char* attributeId, int attributeIndex); // in C++

section.para: more quickstarts can be founded under <BLACKTIE_HOME>/quickstart/nbf, and this quickstart also runs as part of the run_all_quickstarts script.
